entry.title: Technology for the Sake of Humans

content.div: One interesting thing about technology is that it really is pointless outside of a user. Of course there are systems that function without human intervention, but at the end of day, systems function to help users. This is not a revelation or anything insanely profound, but just a little concept that it is good to bring to the forefront every once in a while. You know, to keep it real.

summary.div: The web has been optimized prematurely. People have thought about web applications in terms of PHP and the result is the web as we have it today. It is due for a rewrite and many folks would argue that Web 2.0 is just that, a rewrite of the web. In a way this is true [...]

div.p: The web has been optimized prematurely. People have thought about web applications in terms of PHP and the result is the web as we have it today. It is due for a rewrite and many folks would argue that Web 2.0 is just that, a rewrite of the web. In a way this is true but I would argue that Web 2.0 (we all love buzzwords right?) is really more of a unittest getting things ready for the actual code that will be written.

When I first became interested in computers, it was through Linux. The command line was an interesting application of sorts because there was elegance hidden behind simplicity. It has been said that Google has taken this simplicity and essentially creating find + grep for the web. The best thing about the command line was that it was an application that other applications could use. It is this intrinsic design pattern in Unix that made it such a powerful platform that emphasized reuse and never required optimizations before necessary.

The web on the other hand has made a very specific optimization to hold all the data on a central server to make sure there is no redundancy. Bandwidth has been primarily the responsibility of the server because the data has been placed there. The browser is the input device of choice, which arguably presents security concerns, so no DELETEs or PUTs. Scaling pushed its way to the forefront of web development prematurely and the resulting web applications have been crippled by their own requirements, almost none of which were actually required.

Before I go on, I should mention this is not a rant against PHP or web developers. There are millions of applications on the web that are amazing and effective. What I suggest is simply refactoring to take advantage of new features and get rid of cruft that is not necessary anymore. With that said…

The solution to this is to create a shell for the web. We need stdout and stdin and everything should be a file. Fortunately we already have the workings of it with Atom Publishing Protocol. APP essentially gives life to a file, which is the basis of *nix where everything is a file. APP makes no effort to stop data redundancy or implement a push architecture. APP assumes the user’s client is doing a good job and tries to respect the information it receives. In a nutshell, APP gives the web a file.

Within the scope of SonicRadar, this is crucial. If everything is a file then musicians can mount their files in /home/MyBand and my application read from /home/MyBand/shows to see when they are playing. Even though a network may or may not be involved, I never know and I don’t care to know. If I want to see the shows of different bands playing in my town, it is simply a matter of getting each file and using grep. The idea here is that instead of every web application reimplementing things like ls and cd, we create an environment for people to reuse the basics.
This idea is not new of course. It is simply within reach. SonicRadar will allow everyone to have a true ‘~’ on the web instead of logging into the VPN just to access a silly mapped ‘Z:’ drive.

div.p: I have high hopes for XForms. As someone who is familiar with user interface design and interaction design, I can honestly say that as a developer the cost/reward ratio is skewed. There is a vast amount of work that is required to add features that are arguably inconsequential to better usability. XForms has the ability to reduce the amount work by doing the same type of rendering that the browser provides for HTML. This is huge.

The impact of this means that an interface can be created for a service almost as easily as HTML can be created. I remember when I first learned HTML and saw how simple it was to create a page. Nowadays you see wiki markup and a multitude of text formats that allow easy translation from text to markup. It reflects the practiced boundary between style and content, which has been critical in making the web what it is today. When you think of things like Google Pages or any wiki, you see a situation where the user is asked to provide content which gets styled. The result is that adding content has become easy enough that we have Wikipedia and millions of bloggers.

The next step in this evolution is building forms to get user input and send it to some service. PayPal has done this to some extent but they have had a pretty simple model where a button gets the user 80% of what they need and usually is enough. In a more complex service it would be nice to give someone an example piece of XML and then create forms (via XForms) that submits the XML to the service. Before going on, you should read that sentence again because there is a subtle point to see…

The key phrase there is “give someone an example.” Instead of describing RELAX NG syntax to a service, if someone provides a basic template for what the input should look like, a person could copy and paste it into an XForms editor. The XForms editor creates a quick sample template of the forms and you start adding requirements according to your own needs. Better yet, someone can just give you the forms and be done with it!

The result is that the creativity you see on the web can be applied to interfaces without having to understand event models or callbacks. Sure, there will probably be something of a geocities phase where text areas have animated people walking around the cursor. But, soon after you will see people creating innovative ways to gather data from users. More importantly, users will be able to create their own custom world to use with their favorite services. It will be like the world magically learned Lisp and the web browser became Emacs… You know what I mean… Right?

div.p: Today I went to my local HMV to browse their CDs. I don’t know if you are like me but I often tell myself “you should note this album down and look up for it next time you’ll get there”. Now if you’re anything like me you never do such thing. So it’s usually when I end up at the store that I realize I wanted to search for an artist’s album and fail to remember who and what. Anyway today I was browsing their catalog without much idea of what I wanted except it had to be someone I had never heard. I do so to force myself into listening to different things. I ended up piling up around height CDs.

Now considering the crazy prices HMV applies to some indie or rather unknown bands I wanted to have an idea of what I would buy. I therefore headed towards their (unique) working station where you search for an artist, album or song. If you’re lucky you can listen to it. Hint, I said “If you’re lucky”. Truth is most albums they actually upload there come from famous bands and artists (well that’s far fetched a word in many cases but that’s beside the point). So out of my height albums only one was available to be listened to. I wasn’t moving forward, was I?

Slightly pissed off, I went to ask one of the HMV vendor what the hell was going on. He explained that the machine they used to convert the songs to MP3 was broken and they didn’t know when they’d get a new one. I blinked and I said “what’s the point for me to come down here? I should just download the files from the Internet instead.”. He nodded and looked sorry.

So here we are, huge chains like HMV, which are blaming the piracy and those who don’t pay a penny, cannot even afford a descent streaming system, allowing people to gage an album before spending their cash on it.

I mean when an album costs £15 (around $30) you tend to ensure you will like it as a whole. If I can’t do that at the shop, I will do it online and then, what stops me from actually getting the file for free anyway?
For free? Well yes because when I went to the HMV Digital website I got the following message:

blockquote.p: This site relies on ActiveX technology to download music to your machine; at this time you need Internet Explorer version 6 or greater running on Windows XP or Windows 2000 to purchase and download music.
We hope to add Firefox support soon. In the mean time, why not subscribe to our RSS feeds to keep up to date with the latest releases.

div.p: Now that means that from Linux I can’t get to their service. Well too bad for them. (I will pass on the blatant attempt to make me believe that they will either rewrite their entire application without ActiveX or find a way to support ActiveX from within Firefox natively).
Where does that leave us? Well as the title says “Go figure.”.
Now I did buy three CDs anyway: Pearl Jam - Ten, Little Barrie - We are little barrie, James Harries - Days Like These. I have not been disappointed so far.

a.title: Bellevue Christian Concert Choir @ The Gateway Center, Salt Lake City, UT

p.a: Video: Bellevue Christian Concert Choir @ The Gateway Center, Salt Lake City, UT
p.p: Beyond the performance, and the acoustics of the room, what I found most amazing about this experience was to see how many students had digital cameras with them, and how many of those cameras were video-enabled.

We’re entering a whole new world, my friends, where traditional media can no longer keep up with what’s going on around the world at the same pace that 100 million info-hungry ‘tweeners are as quickly, easily, and affordably equipped as they both are and can be to report the news as it’s happening to anyone with access to the internet. Add to this an equivalent number of 30, 40, and 50 somethings, an increasingly technologically savvy group of retired folk, and, of course, the popularity of sites such as YouTube and I think we can easily assume that within 10 years time the newscasts as we know them will be no longer.
Just my opinion, of course, and I have every reason to believe that these same media agencies will find ways to adapt.

div.p: There has been a good deal of discussion recently regarding offline web applications. The impetus for this conversation stem from Joyent’sSlingshot. Dave’s response was that you don’t need offline web applications and in a way I agree. Joyent’s response cleared up a good deal of confusion and put the concept in context. The short and skinny is that the offline web is partly about working on planes, but primarily is about one means of interfacing with the user.

I should be specific. If you have every programmed a user interface for Windows.Forms with IronPython you quickly realize that Windows.Forms was not meant to typed by humans. The classes are all designed to be created via Visual Studio. There is nothing wrong with it of course and I am sure others would disagree with me. The issue is that designing a user interface is complicated. Think about writing RTF, PostScript, XSL-FO, etc. and you immediately see that making a visual image of something via a text based language is not very easy.

The web browser helps a bit with this and provides a valuable constraint. You don’t get tons of drag and drop controls with datagrid views, but users don’t expect them. You don’t have millions of event handlers (well you could, but you really don’t need them) because the web is stateless. Separating design from content is almost a given and there is an actual divide between the “View” (the rendered HTML) and the “Controller” (whatever the server is doing). The real benefit of “offline” web applications is that you get to program for the web without the web and that is appealing.

This is not a silver bullet of course. On the usability front it potentially makes user interfaces inconsistent. Interesting usability concepts could also be dropped on the floor simply be implementations are too difficult. Another issue is that the platform is regulated by browser makers, which could potentially prevent UI innovation. In a way both of these concerns are valid, but overall I think it really doesn’t matter. Users have learned to use the web and appreciate the benefits they get web applications such that browser based offline applications that help to interact with online services will provide more than enough usefulness to make almost any user interface worth learning. A user interface is nothing without a user, so making applications that have users is a must before trying to make life better for the users.

The concept of interaction with online services is the critical aspect in this whole equation. The WS-* stack has proven itself to somewhat ill suited for generic services, whereas the browser has become an amazing platform for viewing and interacting with information. I believe the Atom Publishing Protocol answers this need by providing a thin, atomic wrapper around the traditional web based interface where clients can be much more affective. With this simple RESTful protocol, offline client applications can easily provide customized interfaces to services while happily staying within the confines of the web browser.

Within the context of SonicRadar, this means creating one system that can be used online or offline through the browser. It means that individuality is no long adding another class to an application on a server. Instead it means providing a new service or creating a new interface to a service. In a way this small distinction is of little consequence to users, but as people more and more accustomed to having their data available online all the times it becomes increasingly important to have control over that data.

By the way, control is not storage of the data. Control is how you interact with data. As a problem solver, I can invert the problem to see another angle in how to solve it. As a web user I am provided a proprietary portal to canned information. What I want is to have many ways to see information. Aggregators provide this very functionality and considering the success of RSS/Atom feeds, I think applying this principle to the entire web makes sense. Offline web applications make this possible because the technology used to provide the services can be used on the client as is and there no longer is a constant battle between developers and the system’s of their users.

Java, C#, Python, Ruby, PHP, etc. all allow programmers to write code without worrying about the operating system. This was not the goal. The goal was to allow programmers to write code without worry about the user’s operating system. The client side web continues this tradition and I am on board.

div.p: I read this article from Dare regarding Open Source being “dead” because social software requires some central element. In a way I agree with him. Social software is essentially just a web application that has many users. It is not the software itself that makes it helpful, it is the marriage of technology and a bountiful user base that gives it value.

The assumption is the browser will always be the interface for social software. I do not think the browser is going away. But I do think that other types of clients will become more important as social software continues to create more than social situations. My favorite example of this is MySpace and the abuse of the profile section. A custom MySpace profile manager would be a nice little application to have for creating slick themes. It would be nice as well to aggregate parts of MySpace to other sites (this would be especially helpful to musicians I think). At this point MySpace breaks down because the entire profile customization system is essentially just a hack. MySpace could benefit by producing a real API for customization that the clients can implement.

This really is just the traditional “Web 3.0″ kind of talk. The idea of moving beyond mash-ups into real deal aggregation of disparate content for a cohesive message. I am doubting MySpace will lead the charge into this kind of space, but you never know. I do think the Open Source community will (and has) lead this movement. Sure they will not be writing the great web service that folks are using, but they will be writing the clients and specs that users enjoy.

div.p: My musical background stems primarily from punk. As I have gotten older and arguably less ‘punk’, I have made an effort to understand what the essence of punk truly is. To me, punk encompasses two primary concepts.

To be “punk” is to be a part of a community. The idea is that without some audience for actions, there is no way to recognize whether you are acting “punk” or not. Beyond the obviousness of an audience, a punk mentality involves a respect for other persons. I say “persons” because the respect is not necessarily for a group of people. Instead, it is important to have respect for each and every person’s individuality.

Before going on I should mention that the “punk” I grew up on was the breed from DC. Minor Threat and Dischord helped define my concept of punk, which was then confirmed as I moved through other punk genres. In other words, I never wore a leather jacket, squatted, did heroin, shaved my head/had a mohawk or did any of the other potentially traditionally punk activities.

In order to be punk you really need to be wary of belief. I am not saying you shouldn’t believe in something, but rather that a person who is punk believes in something because they have asked questions and found answers that drove them to believe something. This is also the root of “questioning authority” or “questioning societal norms” or any other more obvious punk mantra.
To sum it up, being punk is respecting others and making an effort to understand.

Now, I mention this here because up until this point I have discussed the “business” side of music and it is important that folks do not misinterpret who I am. My music is my art and it is how I can express myself and provide something other people can relate to and enjoy. I have found in my questioning of the music industry, that the numerical majority of people involved are honest and caring folks that share in my passions. I know many people see the music industry as a terrible place where musicians lose their souls and sacrifice their integrity for a fleeting few moments of fame while record companies make big bucks at the expense of real of people. While this happens, the majority of people who work in the music industry (this includes the bookers, indie labels, publicists, promoters, musicians, designers, etc.) barely scrape by out of their love of music.

While it may not appear very ‘punk’ to try and help improve the music industry as a whole, it is punk to try. I think every person who goes on a tour, puts out a record or simply goes to see a band live is worth the time if their passion for music can be supported. So, if you think I am always talking like a capitalistic jerk who cares nothing for artistic expression, please have a bit of perspective. I want friends of mine who tour and run labels to have insurance. I want local bands in town to not need to go to the pharmaceutical testing labs every month to pay for recordings. I want clubs to be able to pay touring bands enough for gas *and* food. In other words, no one is saying that folks need huge houses, tons of cars and plastic surgery, simply a reasonable wage for a ton of hard work.

div.p: FreeBoB is now named FFADO which stands for Free Firewire Audio Drivers. FreeBoB is a project that aims at providing support for audio devices using FireWire and espacially the BeBoB firmware. I cannot praise enough for that project considering those guys allowed me to use my M-Audio FireWire Solo on my beloved Linux distribution.
They seem to be changing their name because they plan on supporting any audio device using FireWire. This is a huge news for the entire community and we must welcome their decision.

I would like to say that the support of high end audio devices under Linux is usually poor from the vendors themselves and they should be ashamed since the platform is fantastic for performing audio and music work.

div.p: I read an article on TechCrunch regarding how it was good that CD sales were down. There is an idea major labels make huge margins and the lowered CD sales is the market correcting that. The more I think about these topics the more I wish there was more research on the subject because there is no way to speak authoritatively without really knowing what the books look like. Specifically, the article mentions it will be good when labels realize they cannot make huge profits. Part of me thinks this is good, but overall I wonder then who will make money because if artists are not making it when there is an abundance of funds, I am doubting anything will improve when there is less money to go around.

One theme I see in articles like this is the lack of understanding regarding the amount of work that goes into making a band successful. From the actual music to the company hired to create a slick MySpace theme, there are tons of people involved and most of the time the money must be paid up front without any guarantees on how the record will do. It is similar to venture capital firms in that if the company does not do well, they are simply out of luck. I wonder if there are other industries that have been built off of a rather fickle marketplace and still have relatively traditional profit margins.
